intro: Papaver rhoeas subsp. obtusifolium, commonly known as the blunt-leaf poppy, is a subspecies of the common poppy characterized by its broad, heart-shaped leaves. It produces striking red or orange flowers with a dark center, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. The plant is native to Europe and parts of Asia, often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides. It is an annual herb that grows to a height of about 30–60 cm. The flowers are primarily pollinated by insects, and the plant is known for its ornamental value in gardens.
